items.def: John 18 papyrus dated ~125 CE about 25-50 years after composition relevant because it places the Gospel of John within living memory and shortens the textual gap used to assess authenticity

Papyrus codex dated ~175-225 CE containing Romans 1-2 Corinthians Hebrews Ephesians Galatians Philippians Colossians 1 Thessalonians relevant because it proves an early compiled corpus of Paul that can be cross checked for stability
John and Luke papyri dated ~175-250 CE closely aligned with 4th century codices relevant because early agreement across centuries shows stable transmission
Near complete Greek Bible dated ~325 CE relevant because it provides a full textual baseline to compare with earlier papyri and later medieval copies
Major Greek codex dated ~350 CE relevant because its close agreement with Sinaiticus and earlier papyri supports a coherent textual tradition
About 99.5 percent agreement with differences mostly spelling or word order relevant because high agreement across thousands of witnesses increases confidence in the reconstructed text
Near complete Isaiah dated ~125 BCE relevant because it predates Christianity and matches the medieval Masoretic Text which shows long term OT stability
Qumran Isaiah aligns closely with Masoretic Text 1008 CE relevant because it demonstrates over 1000 years of consistent copying for the Hebrew Bible
Hundreds of biblical manuscripts from 3rd-1st century BCE relevant because they show OT books in circulation well before the NT authors cite them
Bible has far more manuscripts and shorter earliest copy gaps than Homer Plato and Caesar relevant because a larger earlier dataset allows stronger textual reconstruction
